course.title: Harassment Prevention Training (1 Hour)
course.description: California-compliant harassment prevention training for employees. Meets AB 1825 and SB 1343 requirements.

modules.title: Welcome & Legal Context
modules.content:
Welcome to Harassment Prevention Training

This training is required by California law (AB 1825 and SB 1343) for all employees.

Why This Matters

  • Creates a safer, more respectful workplace
  • Protects you and your coworkers
  • Required by law - failure to complete may affect employment
  • Must be completed every 2 years

What You'll Learn

  • What harassment is (and isn't)
  • How to recognize it
  • How to report it
  • What happens after you report
  • Your rights and protections

Time Required: 60 minutes
Passing Score: 80% on final quiz

modules.title: What is Harassment?
modules.content:
Definition of Harassment

Harassment is unwelcome conduct based on a protected characteristic that is severe or pervasive enough to create a hostile work environment.

Protected Characteristics in California (18+)

  • Race, color, ancestry, national origin
  • Religion, creed
  • Age (40 and over)
  • Disability (mental and physical)
  • Sex, gender, gender identity, gender expression
  • Sexual orientation
  • Marital status
  • Military/veteran status
  • Genetic information
  • Medical condition
  • Pregnancy, childbirth, breastfeeding
  • And more...

Key Terms

Severe: A single serious incident (like physical assault or extreme verbal abuse)

Pervasive: Repeated incidents that create an intimidating, hostile, or offensive environment

Hostile Environment: Conduct that unreasonably interferes with work performance or creates an intimidating, hostile, or offensive workplace

modules.title: Types of Harassment
modules.content:
Forms of Harassment

1. Verbal Harassment

  • Offensive jokes or comments
  • Slurs or epithets
  • Derogatory remarks about appearance, accent, or background
  • Unwanted sexual comments or propositions
  • Threats or intimidation

2. Physical Harassment

  • Unwanted touching or physical contact
  • Assault or battery
  • Physical blocking or impeding movement
  • Unwanted sexual advances

3. Visual Harassment

  • Offensive posters, cartoons, or drawings
  • Inappropriate emails or texts with offensive content
  • Lewd gestures
  • Displaying sexually suggestive objects or pictures

4. Digital Harassment (NEW 2026)

  • Offensive emails, texts, or social media messages
  • Cyberbullying
  • Sharing explicit images without consent
  • Online stalking or monitoring

Important: Harassment doesn't have to be intentional. Impact matters more than intent.

questions.text: Which of the following is a protected characteristic under California law?
questions.explanation: Gender identity is one of 18+ protected characteristics under FEHA. Political affiliation, job performance, and education level are not protected.

questions.text: Harassment must be intentional to be illegal.
questions.explanation: False. The impact of the conduct matters more than the intent. Even if someone didn't mean to offend, their actions can still constitute harassment.

modules.title: Real-World Examples
modules.content:
What Harassment Looks Like

Scenario 1: Racial Harassment

Situation: Maria, a Latina employee, hears coworkers making jokes about immigrants during lunch breaks. The jokes continue despite her visible discomfort.

This IS harassment: Offensive comments about national origin, repeated behavior, creating a hostile environment.

Scenario 2: Sexual Harassment

Situation: A supervisor repeatedly comments on an employee's appearance, makes suggestive remarks, and sends flirtatious texts after work hours.

This IS harassment: Unwelcome sexual conduct, abuse of power, pervasive behavior.

Scenario 3: Disability Harassment

Situation: Coworkers mock an employee with a speech impediment, imitating their voice and laughing.

This IS harassment: Conduct based on disability, creating hostile environment.

Scenario 4: Not Harassment

Situation: A manager gives constructive criticism about work quality and sets performance expectations.

This is NOT harassment: Legitimate job-related feedback, even if uncomfortable, is not harassment.

Scenario 5: Age Harassment

Situation: Younger employees repeatedly call older coworkers 'grandpa' or make jokes about retirement.

This IS harassment: Age-based comments creating hostile environment.

questions.text: A supervisor gives an employee a negative performance review. Is this harassment?
options: Yes, because it makes the employee uncomfortable
No, legitimate job feedback is not harassment
Only if the employee is in a protected class
Yes, if it happens more than once
questions.explanation: Legitimate job-related feedback and discipline are not harassment, even if uncomfortable. Harassment must be based on a protected characteristic.

modules.title: Abusive Conduct
modules.content:
Understanding Abusive Conduct (Workplace Bullying)

California law (SB 1343) requires training on abusive conduct - malicious behavior that a reasonable person would find hostile or offensive, and that is not related to legitimate business interests.

Examples of Abusive Conduct

  • Repeated verbal abuse
  • Threats, humiliation, or intimidation
  • Sabotage of work performance
  • Exploitation of known psychological or physical vulnerabilities

Key Difference from Harassment

Harassment: Based on a protected characteristic (race, gender, etc.)

Abusive Conduct: May not be based on protected status, but is still malicious and hostile

Example: A manager consistently yells at, belittles, and publicly humiliates an employee for minor mistakes. Even if not based on a protected characteristic, this is abusive conduct.

Both Are Prohibited

Your employer must prevent and address both harassment AND abusive conduct.

modules.title: Your Right to Report
modules.content:
How to Report Harassment

You have the right and responsibility to report harassment or abusive conduct.

Multiple Reporting Channels

  1. Your Direct Supervisor
    Tell your immediate manager
  2. Any Manager
    If uncomfortable with your supervisor, talk to any management employee
  3. HR Department
    Contact: hr@[company].com or (XXX) XXX-XXXX
  4. Anonymous Hotline
    Call: 1-800-XXX-XXXX
  5. Written Complaint
    Submit complaint form (available on HR portal)

What to Include in Your Report

  • What happened (be specific)
  • When it happened (dates, times)
  • Where it happened
  • Who was involved
  • Witnesses (if any)
  • Any evidence (emails, texts, photos)

Important: You do NOT need proof to report. If you experienced or witnessed harassment, report it.

You Don't Have to Use the Word 'Harassment'

Simply describe what happened. HR will determine if it constitutes harassment.

questions.text: If you experience harassment, you must report it to your direct supervisor first.
questions.explanation: False. You can report to ANY manager, HR, or use an anonymous hotline. You have multiple reporting options.

questions.text: You need proof before you can report harassment.
questions.explanation: False. You do NOT need proof to report. If you experienced or witnessed something concerning, report it. The investigation will gather evidence.

modules.title: The Investigation Process
modules.content:
What Happens After You Report

Investigation Timeline

  1. Immediate Response (24-48 hours)
    HR acknowledges your complaint and may separate parties if needed
  2. Investigation Begins (Within 1 week)
    A trained investigator is assigned
  3. Interviews Conducted (1-3 weeks)
    Investigator interviews: complainant, accused, witnesses
  4. Evidence Review
    Review emails, documents, any physical evidence
  5. Findings Determined (3-4 weeks total)
    Investigation concludes with findings
  6. Action Taken
    If harassment occurred, corrective action is implemented
  7. Follow-Up
    HR checks in to ensure no retaliation

Investigation Standards

Fair: Both parties have opportunity to present their side

Thorough: All relevant evidence is reviewed

Timely: Completed as quickly as possible (usually 2-4 weeks)

Confidential: Information shared only on need-to-know basis

What You Can Expect

  • Your report will be taken seriously
  • You will be interviewed (possibly multiple times)
  • You may need to provide evidence
  • You will be informed of the general outcome
  • Your identity will be kept confidential to extent possible

modules.title: Anti-Retaliation Protections
modules.content:
You Are Protected from Retaliation

It is ILLEGAL to retaliate against someone for:

  • Reporting harassment or discrimination
  • Participating in an investigation
  • Opposing discriminatory practices
  • Filing a complaint with the Civil Rights Department or EEOC

What Is Retaliation?

Retaliation is any adverse action taken against you because you engaged in protected activity.

Examples of Retaliation

  • Termination or demotion
  • Pay reduction or denial of promotion
  • Negative performance reviews
  • Exclusion from meetings or opportunities
  • Hostile treatment by coworkers
  • Increased scrutiny or unfair discipline
  • Schedule changes that disadvantage you

Retaliation Doesn't Have to Be Direct

Example: After Maria reports harassment, her supervisor starts excluding her from important meetings and giving her less desirable assignments.

This is retaliation - even though she wasn't fired.

If You Experience Retaliation

  1. Document everything (dates, incidents, witnesses)
  2. Report it immediately to HR or management
  3. The company must investigate and stop retaliation

Retaliation is often easier to prove than the original harassment and can result in significant legal penalties.

questions.text: Which of the following could be retaliation?
options: Being excluded from meetings after filing a complaint
Receiving a poor performance review after reporting harassment
Being terminated shortly after participating in an investigation
questions.explanation: All of these could be retaliation. Any adverse action following protected activity (reporting, participating in investigation) may constitute illegal retaliation.

modules.title: Bystander Intervention
modules.content:
What To Do If You Witness Harassment

You have a responsibility to act if you witness harassment.

The 5 D's of Bystander Intervention

1. DIRECT

Intervene directly if safe to do so: 'That's not appropriate' or 'We don't talk like that here.'

2. DISTRACT

Interrupt the situation: Change the subject, ask a question, create a distraction.

3. DELEGATE

Get help from someone with more authority: supervisor, HR, security.

4. DELAY

Check on the target after the incident: 'Are you okay?' 'That wasn't right.'

5. DOCUMENT

Write down what you saw (date, time, what happened, who was involved) and report it.

Example Scenarios

Scenario: You overhear coworkers making racist jokes in the break room.

Action: 'Hey, that's not cool. Let's change the subject.' (DIRECT) or Report to HR (DELEGATE)

Scenario: You see a manager touching an employee's shoulder repeatedly despite their discomfort.

Action: Interrupt: 'Hey Sarah, can I borrow you for a minute?' (DISTRACT) then check in later (DELAY) and report (DOCUMENT)

Why Bystander Intervention Matters

  • Shows support for the target
  • Signals that harassment is not acceptable
  • Can stop escalation
  • Creates a culture of accountability

questions.text: If you witness harassment but the target doesn't seem bothered, you should:
options: Do nothing - it's not your business
Still report it - impact matters more than reaction
Only intervene if the person asks for help
Wait to see if it happens again
questions.explanation: You should still report it. Some people don't react visibly due to shock, fear, or workplace dynamics. Harassment is judged by a 'reasonable person' standard, not the target's immediate reaction.

modules.title: Special Topics: 2026 Updates
modules.content:
New Protections (2026 Updates)

1. Reproductive Health Protection (SB 523)

You CANNOT be harassed or discriminated against based on:

  • Use of contraception
  • Fertility treatments
  • Pregnancy decisions
  • Pregnancy loss
  • Abortion

Example: Asking 'When are you planning to have kids?' in an interview or making comments about an employee's IVF treatments is prohibited.

2. Cannabis Use Protection (AB 2188)

Employers generally cannot discriminate based on off-duty cannabis use (except for certain positions).

Note: On-duty impairment is still prohibited.

3. LGBTQ+ Protections

California law explicitly protects:

  • Sexual orientation
  • Gender identity
  • Gender expression

This includes using correct pronouns, respecting chosen names, and access to appropriate facilities.

4. Remote Work Harassment

Harassment in virtual settings (Zoom, Teams, email, Slack) is covered under the same protections.

Examples: Inappropriate comments in video meetings, offensive messages in chat, excluding someone from virtual meetings based on protected characteristic.

questions.text: Which of the following is protected under 2026 California law?
questions.explanation: All of the above are protected under 2026 California law. SB 523 protects reproductive health, AB 2188 protects off-duty cannabis use, and FEHA protects gender identity/expression.

modules.title: Creating a Respectful Workplace
modules.content:
We All Have a Role

Beyond Legal Compliance

Preventing harassment isn't just about following the law - it's about creating a workplace where everyone feels safe, valued, and respected.

What You Can Do

  • Treat everyone with respect regardless of differences
  • Speak up when you see or hear something inappropriate
  • Be an ally to coworkers who may be vulnerable
  • Think before you speak - consider how your words might impact others
  • Listen when someone expresses discomfort
  • Apologize if you make a mistake
  • Report concerns promptly

Building an Inclusive Culture

An inclusive workplace is one where:

  • Everyone feels they belong
  • Diverse perspectives are valued
  • People can bring their authentic selves to work
  • Differences are celebrated, not tolerated
  • Everyone has equal opportunities

The Impact of Your Actions

Every interaction matters. Your words and actions shape workplace culture.

Choose to be part of creating a positive, respectful environment for all.

modules.title: Resources & Final Assessment
modules.content:
External Resources

California Civil Rights Department (CRD)

Website: calcivilrights.ca.gov
Phone: 1-800-884-1684
File a complaint: Online at CRD website

Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)

Website: eeoc.gov
Phone: 1-800-669-4000
File a complaint: Within 300 days of incident

Company Resources

  • HR Department: hr@[company].com
  • Anonymous Hotline: 1-800-XXX-XXXX
  • Employee Handbook: [Link]
  • Anti-Harassment Policy: [Link]
  • Complaint Form: [Link]

Review Key Points

  • Harassment is unwelcome conduct based on protected characteristics
  • 18+ protected classes in California
  • Report to supervisor, any manager, HR, or anonymous hotline
  • Multiple forms: verbal, physical, visual, digital
  • Retaliation is illegal - you are protected
  • Bystanders have a responsibility to intervene
  • Company will investigate promptly and thoroughly
  • Everyone has a role in creating respectful culture

Ready for your final assessment?
You must score 80% to pass. You have unlimited attempts.

questions.text: How many protected characteristics does California law recognize?
questions.explanation: California law protects 18+ characteristics including race, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, age, disability, and many more.

questions.text: True or False: You must experience harassment personally to report it.
questions.explanation: False. If you witness harassment, you should report it. Bystanders have a responsibility to intervene and report.

questions.text: What is the first thing you should do if you experience harassment?
options: Tell your friends but not HR
questions.explanation: Report it through available channels (supervisor, HR, hotline). The company must investigate and take action.

questions.text: How often must California employees complete harassment prevention training?
questions.explanation: Every 2 years. California law requires harassment prevention training every two years.
